newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgaria lev dips on short-covering ahead of poll.
newsitem.headline: Bulgaria lev dips on short-covering ahead of poll.

text.p: The Bulgarian lev eased to 1,510-1,515 per dollar before midday from the opening 1,500-1,510 on short-covering ahead of Saturday's general elections, dealers said.
"The lev dipped by around 10 per dollar as dollar demand from banks rose on short covering ahead of the poll after recent dollar sales," a commercial bank dealer said.
Banks hedged protectively against any risks although no reversal in economic reforms launched by the interim cabinet was expected after the elections, traders said.

The interim cabinet in office since mid-February until after the elections has won pledges of some $1.2 billion from international lenders providing long-term support for the country's move towards a market economy.
Most banks had pared foreign exchange positions recently to profit on high yield government securities and were now short covering, dealers said.
The lev has traded stable between 1,500-1,600 per dollar for more than a month.
A cut in the Bulgarian National Bank (BNB) main interest rate, effective on Monday, might also have been a factor for today's lev drop but not a significant one, dealers said.
"Yield of lev-denominated instruments would still be higher as no sharp lev fall is anticipated," another dealer said.
The BNB said it would cut its main interest rate to 8.03 percent monthly from 14.15 percent in line with falling yield on short term government securuities.
The new rate compared with a projected monthly inflation rate for April below the March's 12.3 percent.
